text: you have to loop over all your album_ids. In every loop collect the tracks - do that extend magic in case the album has more than 50, thereby populating a temporary track list `all_tracks_album`. text:
Hi! I'm having some trouble because of this:
My initial playlist has 151 songs and, as expected, was truncating at 100 results. So I did the for loop to get the 151 songs and stored it into a list called 'track_id'. The problem is that when I try to get the audio features of these 151 songs like this:
audio_feat=sp.audio_features(tracks=track_id)
it gives me error because I think this function only accepts 100 results instead of 151. Does anyone know how to get the audio features from a list of ids bigger thatn 100?
THXXXX :heart:

normally you go from str to float to int… is there a reason you need it to be a float, not an int? If this is for the audio features, you can also try
```df['DataFrame Column'] = pd.to_numeric(df['DataFrame Column'],errors='coerce')```

text: what you need to do is drop this column from your data frame before clustering, and then once you have the cluster, you can return the track identifier. an ID is never needed for machine learning, perhaps you just forgot that as we are in a different context. similarly, anything else that is a like type, track uri - none are required for your clustering process- just the audio features

text:
<!channel>,
The question came up twice:
if you think about merging two dataframes on an ID (a song ID for example), make sure your two dataframes ID's are unique. You can check so if `len(df1['id'].unique())`  is equal to `len(df1['id'])` . In case you have duplicates with respect to the ID column, you need to drop the duplicates (for example with `df1 = df1.drop_duplicates(subset=['id'])` otherwise you get an "explode" of your rows... imagine 30 duplicate rows in one df want to join 20 counterparts in another df, that makes it 600 additional columns....

elements.text:
,
The question came up twice:
if you think about merging two dataframes on an ID (a song ID for example), make sure your two dataframes ID's are unique. You can check so if
len(df1['id'].unique())
is equal to
len(df1['id'])
. In case you have duplicates with respect to the ID column, you need to drop the duplicates (for example with
df1 = df1.drop_duplicates(subset=['id'])
otherwise you get an "explode" of your rows... imagine 30 duplicate rows in one df want to join 20 counterparts in another df, that makes it 600 additional columns....

text:
<!channel>,
another thing:
One student collected the audio features (which come as dictionaries out of `sp.audiofeatures(<some_track_id>)` ) in a list, let's say `audio_feats_lst`. Not a bad idea, since you can directly feed that to a dataframe:
```feature_df = pd.DataFrame(audio_feats_lst)```
But it threw an Error "NoneType attribute has no attribute .keys()". The reason was, there was one empty dictionary hiding in the list (which of course had no attribute .keys()  - because of something went wrong when querying the API - we basicall don't care for only a few songs missing....

One solution is: You can try to quickly filter your `audio_feats_lst` for empty dictionaries with:
```audio_feats_clean = [dct for dct in audio_feats_lst if dct]```
that if condition at the end checks if `dct` is empty, because the bool value of empty stuff in Python is mostly False

elements.text:
,
another thing:
One student collected the audio features (which come as dictionaries out of
sp.audiofeatures(<some_track_id>)
) in a list, let's say
audio_feats_lst
. Not a bad idea, since you can directly feed that to a dataframe:
feature_df = pd.DataFrame(audio_feats_lst)

But it threw an Error "NoneType attribute has no attribute .keys()". The reason was, there was one empty dictionary hiding in the list (which of course had no attribute .keys()  - because of something went wrong when querying the API - we basicall don't care for only a few songs missing....

One solution is: You can try to quickly filter your
audio_feats_lst
for empty dictionaries with:
audio_feats_clean = [dct for dct in audio_feats_lst if dct]
that if condition at the end checks if
dct
is empty, because the bool value of empty stuff in Python is mostly False
